lines.text: Put a cork in it, you're giving me a headache.
I don't have a cork.
Shut your mouth.
I can't because my nose is stuffy, because of my allergies. If I shut my mouth, I can't breathe good.
Then keep your mouth open, but don't talk.
Where do you put the cork when you put a cork in it?

[Pants irritably a couple times]
Didn't I ask you to shut your yap?
What's a yap?
It's your mouth!
I can't shut my mouth because my nose is stuffy -...
SHUT UP!
[echoes]
However, you're dealing with him. He hasn't learned it's not good manners to break in on a fella and shoot an aspirin down his throat.
Oh, Mr. Wilson, he's 5.
When I was 5, I had some respect.
Well, you're probably a pretty exceptional boy.
In 1925, I was not the exception; I was the rule.

[sees Dennis being helped by Gunther in a game of hide-and-seek]
He's cheating.
What are you doing?
Dennis is cheating. He's using the Beckman kid as a spy.
Oh, leave them alone, George.
I'm gonna even things up. Gunther?
[Gunther looks up]
Gunther, I'm just talking to your daddy on the telephone. He's going to the ice cream store. He wants to take you with him.
[Gunther gasps in excitement]
Hurry up and go home!
[Gunther goes cross-eyed and runs off]

[chuckles]
Now it's fair.
[Mr. Wilson sighs as he sits back down]
You lied to a toddler, George!
[Mr. Wilson continues chuckling]
Well, think how disappointed he's going to be when he gets home!
Well, he better get used to it. Disappointment's gonna be a big part of his life. He's a foot short for his age and he's cross-eyed.
[Mrs. Wilson glares at him]
Weren't you a fat boy?
I was husky.
[in bed at night]
George, are you sleeping?
I was until you started yaking.
I'm sorry.
Was Dennis in our bathroom?
Yes.
I think the little rat put mouthwash in my nasal spray and toilet cleanser in my mouthwash.
Why would he do something like that?

[smiles sarcastically]
Must you ask?

[angry about Alice Mitchell's cancelled flight]
Over my dead body! This is the crowning moment of my retired life, and I'm not throwing it away like the evening trash for some ninny who can't get her keister to the airport on time!
George Wilson, you have no right to insult Alice! She can't help the weather any more than you or I.
Well, she...
It's just plain bad luck! It's no one's fault.
A tragedy of this magnitude has to be somebody's fault, Martha!
It isn't a tragedy! A little boy's going to join us for a party. Uh, if you want to forsake your neighbors when they need help, you do it alone.
Why is it when everyone else feasts on the pleasure of life, I get the indigestion?
Because you're an old grump!
How old is this bed?
It belonged to my mother.
Where's she sleeping now?
She's been gone many years, Dennis.
On business?
No, she's in Heaven.
Oh, there's an awful lot of people in Heaven, especially old people.

[about her doll being stolen by Switchblade Sam]
You guys don't understand! Baby Louise is a very expensive antique!
Nobody robbed your doll, Margaret. Maybe a bear ate it.
What?
Yeah, there's no robbers in our town.
You know why men are so lousey when it comes to taking care of babies?
They have better things to do.
Like what? Play golf and drink beer?
No, like hunting, having wars, driving cars, shaving, cleaning fish. Do you know how to do that?
Me?
Margaret.
Oh, okay.
If you didn't have women, you wouldn't have babies, which means you wouldn't have people.
And if you didn't have men, who'd drive the ladies to the hospital?
Hi, Mrs. Wilson. Is Mr. Wilson up yet?
Not yet, dear.
How long do you think he's gonna sleep for?
Not too much longer. He's having his picture taken this morning.
For what?
He's being honored for his garden.

[pauses and looks back at the yard, then looks at Mrs. Wilson again]
Do you think he'll get mad if I went up the stairs.
What do you want to go upstairs for?
I made him a "I'm Sorry, I Shot Paint On Your Chicken" card!
Well, that's very nice, Dennis.
I brought my own pillow so I won't get my spit all over yours.
Thank you, Dennis.
[Mr. Wilson goes disgusted]
I can't stand that kid, he's a menace!
[turns on bathroom light and walks in but slips on wet soapy floor, doing a full split at the legs]

[grabs hold of the sink, to pull himself up]
New pajamas. God bless them.
[opens medicine cabinet and takes toilet-cleaner mouthwash out. He pours some and gargles on it and then spits it out groaning in disgust]

[hearing him from upstairs]
Poor thing, I wish he'd get the hernia fixed.
[has mouth on running faucet as he's trying to frantically rinse his mouth]
[sniffling now, he reaches for the nasal spray-mouth wash. He squeezes some up one nostril. Squeezes up the other nostril. His face goes wild as he drops the container]
[howling wildly he plunges his head in the sink full of water and desperately tries cleaning his nose]

[sees Dennis in the printing room]
Aren't you supposed to be in the daycare area with the other... children?
That's where I was, but I had to leave, because the lady that watches all the kids said if she had to look at me for five more seconds...
[Dennis's mother looks in and smiles knowing Andrea will get what she deserves]
...she'd jump out the window.

[chuckles]
Humph.
She's a pretty nice lady, so I wouldn't want her to do that.
This things been here our whole life and we never knew it.
Do you think anybody lived in it?
Just squirrels and birds.
It looks kind of junky.
We'll fix it up.
Oh, good, I'll be the decorator. We'll put on a special room for the babies and a powder room for when we have company.
Forts don't have powder rooms.
Oh, really? Where do the soldiers' wives go to freshen up?
Soldiers don't have wives, stupid.
Don't call me stupid, baby rump kisser!
The most important thing is they marry the women, then the women can go down and get the baby.
The baby is in her stomach.
She has to get it installed. Her stomach isn't just filled up with babies.
Who installed some?
A minister and a doctor.
How?
'How'?

[laughs]
She wants to know how?
[Joey continues laughing but stops as Margaret furiosuly glares at him]
Tell me, Dennis. How?
The bellybutton-it opens up.
How come men have them?
So they don't look weird in bathing suits.
[Margaret goes disapproved]
You go sit in the corner and think about what you've done.
For how long?
Until you're sorry.
Oh good, I'm sorry now.
He can't sit in the corner, I have to take him to Margaret Wade's house.

[screams in horror scaring his parents]
Margaret's house? I didn't do anything bad enough to deserve to go to her house. She's a lunatic, I'll go crazy, she tortures me, she's mean, she's ugly, she doesn't share!
Honey, I made arrangements with Mrs. Wade for you to go to their house while I work.
Are you serious?
Well, you can't spend the summer unsupervised. You're out of school.

[loses it]
*I'll go back*!
You're mother made arrangements. That's it! I don't want any arguments!

[lightly bows his head on the table]
My life is falling apart.

[reading Dennis a story]
How can a train grow?
He eats all his coal and gets plenty of sleep.
No, like, what's the point of reading lies?
It teaches kids to eat all their food, and go to bed when they're supposed to, and not cry when mean cabooses and box cars make fun of him.

[looking at Mr. Wilson's gold]
Is that Pirate's Gold?
No.
Is it real valuable?
Yes.
Is that why you keep it in your safe?
Uh-huh.

[looks at Mr. Wilson's safe with a door of fake books]
How come that safe looks like books?
How come you ask so many questions?
I've only been around for 5 years. There's a lot of stuff I don't know.
I have one more question.
What?
What does a hostage have to do?
Nothing.
Then how come you need one?
In case the cops show up!
Do I get to use a gun?
No, you get to stand in front of me in case the cops use a gun.

[smiles at party]
Well, Dennis, you're mother did not arrive.
Nope.
This is an important event for me, Dennis.
I know.
I, uh, don't want any nonsense. You mind whatever manners you have and don't make a pest of yourself.
Okay.

[ruffles his hair real hard and leaves]
Don't embarrass me.
Okay.
[Dennis hears and sees elderly ladies near him]

[under his breath]
Cheek pinchers!
You guys are the boring ones. There's lots to do.
Oh, really? Like what?
We could practice singing songs or put on a play or a puppet show.
We could bury you alive.
I could pound your face.
[Mr. Wilson approaches, covered in flour]
He's only a boy, huh?
You've got everything figured out, haven't you, Mr. Wilson?
I haven't figured out yet how I'm gonna get my work done with you in the house.
That's a tough one.
[Dennis is looking into a voyeur of women magazine]
Holy smokes, you gotta be pretty brave to ride on a tiger in your underpants.
Put that away, that's not for kids.
George, take Dennis's suitcase up to the guest room, please.
He's got arms.
Don't you start, dear.
Martha! Where are the GD garden lanterns?
[the others see the mess Dennis has made. Some people start taking pictures of it]

[sensing George getting mad]
Now, George, take it easy.
[glares at Dennis]

[looks back guiltily]
I made a mistake?
[just glares back]

[after missing flower show, goes up to flower and grumbles]
40 years down the drain.
[plucks it up and throws it off]
I don't believe I've seen you around here before.
Maybe that's 'cause I ain't never been around here.
What are you up to, buddy?
What's it to ya?
Now look, I run a nice clean town here, and I don't want any trouble. So, my advice to you is just follow the sun on out of here.
The only reason I ain't moving on is 'cause you stopped to give me the breeze.
[Switchblade Sam grins exposing his ugly teeth, clicks them together, and leaves with a woman's purse he stole from a baby's carraige]

[brushing his teeth spots Mr. Wilson's nasal spray. He opens it up and squirts it]
Cool! Old faithful!
[suddenly it runs out]
[uses the mouthwash to fill it back up. But now the mouthwash is empty]
[uses toilet cleanser to fill the mouthwash up]

[singing and splashing around in bathtub]
She'll be coming around the mountain when she comes! She'll be coming -
[soapy water splashes onto floor]
Hi. This is Alice Mitchell.
Noooooo.
I'm sorry I'm not having a very fun camping trip.
Nobody shoots a marble at my head and sets my pants on fire!
That was an accident.

[picks him up and stands him up]
There ain't gonna be no more accidents! Turn around!
[Dennis shrugs and does so, Sam ties up Dennis's legs with rope]
You're doing it wrong.
Get lost. I tied up lots of guys in my life.
Okay, but I bet you never tied up a five-year-old. I'll just get out.
I'll make this rope so tight, you won't be able to move.

The rope's too big and my legs are too small to make it tight enough. There's only one way to do it, and I know because lots of people have tried to tie me up, but it doesn't work. But you try it your way. I'll just get out and you'll just have to keep doing it.
G.D. wading pool!

[innocently]
Hi.
Did you shoot an aspirin into Mr.Wilson's mouth?
Oh god!
I didn't want him to bite off my fingers with his big, fake teeth. Those things are sharp!

[to Henry]
George said Dennis shot an aspirin into his mouth with a slingshot.
What slingshot?
Do you have a slingshot?
I'm not sure.
Give it to me.
[Dennis sighs and hands over the slingshot]
Hi, mom.
Good morning.
I hear you're trying to beg off the Oklahoma City trip.
I asked that it be rescheduled.
Have a Cub Scout meeting or something?
My husband has a trip at the same time. His was scheduled before mine.
So, if you and your husband travel at the same time, there's no one to watch your kid. Is that the problem?
It's not a problem, per se.

Oh, good. Because if you want to blow off your trip, I'm the one who has to cover for you, and I have plans I can't break. I don't have kids but I do have a life. I'm sorry. I'm just not gonna be able to help you.
[Andrea leaves]
God...
Who else has a night-blooming mock orchid flowering this year?
It's an awfully homely-looking plant, George.
Hang the looks at the thing! It opens before your eyes in the light of a full moon. It's a marvel, Martha. 40 years to mature and blossom. The flower opens and withers in a matter of moments.
[Mr. and Mrs. Wilson approach a rare mock orchid kept alive for 40 years]
There isn't a gardener in town who has a plant that requires a 40-year investment for ten seconds of splendor.

[in an attempt to give Mr. Wilson his 'I'm Sorry' card]
I'm kind of busy today, so I won't have a chance to give it to him. I have to go to Margaret's house, because we're getting poor and my mom's got a job now. So could I just leave it up by his whisker-cutter? That's where I leave all my dad's 'Sorry' cards, and it's a good time to say you're sorry. 'Cause grownup guys are happy in the morning when they wake up. My dad's so happy, he whistles when he goes to the bathroom. The only time he isn't happy is on Sunday morning when he and my mom wrestle. They kind of like to be alone when they do that. I think it's 'cause they take off their shirts and then they start to make funny noises.

[uncomfortable about what Dennis is saying]
Uh, you can go up, as long as you promise not to disturb Mr. Wilson.
I promise.
[first lines]
Hey, Mr. Wilson!
[last lines]

[is stuck to the printer from Dennis]
Oh, I'm gonna get that little kid!
Where are you going?

[mad at him for his apathy]
To make myself a cup of tea.
I didn't decree that we wouldn't have children, Martha. It was out of both our hands.
This isn't about having children or not having children, George. You missed the point. It's about my feeling, something very good and not being able to tell you about it.

[after hearing about Dennis shooting a pill in Mr. Wilson's Mouth]
I'm Sorry about this Morning.
Your kid is driving me nuts.
I'll talk to him again.
Maybe it isn't talk that he needs, when my father had something to tell me, he told me with his belt.
That's not how I deal with my son, George.
[Dennis has just put paint Mr. Wilson's barbequed chicken]
Tastes like paint and wood.
I'll make us some sandwiches.

[while at a business meeting]
You see, when I go to the mall with my little boy, we can't get out unless we visit the toy store. I mean, he knows he's not gonna get anything unless it's a special occasion or something like that, but like every other little kid; he just wants to go in and look around.
Could you spare us the family anecdotes please?

[upon discovering that Switchblade Sam had stolen Mr. Wilson's gold]
This is Mr. Wilson's gold. How come you got it?
I stole it.
You're a robber?
I'm a thief.
Uh-oh.
Say your prayers, little rat!
I can't, I didn't take my bath yet.
Have it your own way!
[as Sam readies his knife on Dennis, the train arrives and the rope tied on him sticks him to the ceiling, he then lands back into the water and is stabbed in the butt by his own blade]
Hi, Mr Mitchell.
Hello Polly, come on in.
[Polly enters the house]
What's the helmet for?
Oh my girlfriend used to babysit for Dennis, she said to bring a helmet and wear pants.

You're a pest. A menace. A selfish, spoiled little boy and I've no use for you. You took something from me that I can never get back, something that means more to me than you ever will. You understand? I don't want to see you, I don't want to know you. Get out of my way.
[George walks away]

[in tears]
I'm sorry, Mr. Wilson.
